sentences.text: On 24 May 2024, a landslide occurred in Maip Muritaka Rural LLG|Mulitaka, Papua New Guinea. By 7 June, 12 bodies had been recovered, with thousands more buried and presumed dead, though estimates of the death toll vary greatly, with some estimating that only 160 had died.

references.text: <ref name="rnz12">{{cite news |title='Mass burial site': PNG landslide death toll remains unknown |url=https://www.rnz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/519363/mass-burial-site-png-landslide-death-toll-remains-unknown |access-date=14 June 2024 |work=Radio New Zealand |language=en |archive-date=14 June 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240614045744/https://www.rnz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/519363/mass-burial-site-png-landslide-death-toll-remains-unknown |url-status=live }}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news |last=Dziedzic |first=Stephen |date=2024-05-31 |title='The earth is moving': PNG PM explains why he can't send excavators to site of landslide disaster |url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-05-31/first-look-at-the-png-landslide-site/103920178 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240601132827/https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-05-31/first-look-at-the-png-landslide-site/103920178 |archive-date=1 June 2024 |access-date=2024-05-31 |work=ABC News |language=en-AU}}</ref>

sentences.text: Papua New Guinea has regularly experienced fatal landslides resulting from its mountainous terrain, weather, climate, poverty, poor land use practices and government mismanagement. In 2024, the country saw intense rainfall and flooding,

references.text: <ref name="LeMonde" /> and in April, 14 people died in a landslide, while 21 died in a landslide one month earlier.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Thorpe |first=Andrew |date=24 May 2024 |title=Why does Papua New Guinea experience so many fatal landslides — and what can be done? |url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-05-24/landslides-papua-new-guinea-explainer-fatalities-climate-change/103889538 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240524131257/https://amp.abc.net.au/article/103889538 |archive-date=24 May 2024 |access-date=2024-05-24 |website=Australian Broadcasting Corporation}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 18 May, a {{M|w|link=y}} 4.5 earthquake occurred {{cvt|105|km|mi}} west of where the landslide happened. It struck {{cvt|126.2|km|mi}} below the surface and has been suggested as a possible cause of the landslide.<ref name="CNN" /> However, the Red Cross has stated that there was no indication that the earthquake caused the landslide, instead attributing it to either Mining in Papua New Guinea|gold mining or heavy rain.<ref name="LeMonde" />

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |author= |date=24 May 2024 |title=M 4.5 – 96 km WNW of Porgera, Papua New Guinea |url=https://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/eventpage/us6000mzdw/executive |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240524110007/https://earthquake.usgs.gov/earthquakes/eventpage/us6000mzdw/executive |archive-date=24 May 2024 |access-date=24 May 2024 |publisher=United States Geological Survey}}</ref>

sentences.text: Papua New Guinea's prime minister James Marape has blamed climate change for the disaster.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |last=Coren |first=Anna |date=29 May 2024 |title=Papua New Guinea PM blames climate crisis for deadly landslide |url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/world/papua-new-guinea-pm-blames-climate-crisis-for-deadly-landslide/vi-BB1njg4K |url-status=live |work=CNN |access-date=31 May 2024 |archive-date=30 May 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240530150441/https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/world/papua-new-guinea-pm-blames-climate-crisis-for-deadly-landslide/vi-BB1njg4K }}</ref>

sentences.text: The landslide occurred at approximately 03:00 Time in Papua New Guinea|PGT on 24 May 2024 (17:00 UTC on 23 May), after a large amount of debris was dislodged from the limestone slopes of Mount Mungalo. The landslide destroyed six villages in Maip Muritaka Rural LLG. It blocked a highway near the Porgera Gold Mine, and destroyed {{Convert|150|m}} of the main highway leading into Kaokalam, causing concerns over the supply of fuel and goods. The mine's management said that its regular operations were unaffected and that fuel at the site was enough to sustain the facility for 40 days. A road construction crew working on the highway was also buried in the landslide.

sentences.text: Approximately 2,000 people were buried and presumed dead in Tulipana village. The Highlands Highway connecting the area to Port Moresby, the capital, was also blocked. Gardens which provided food for the village and its three water streams were buried and destroyed. An official of the International Organization for Migration estimated that the area covered by the landslide was the equivalent of between "three and four football fields<!-- American football or American soccer? -->". The debris was estimated to be {{Convert|6|m}} to {{Convert|8|m}} deep.

sentences.text: Conflicting estimates of casualties emerged following the disaster, which was attributed to the lack of updated population statistics since the last national census in 2000 and the fact that the affected area also hosted pubs catering to miners from other villages On 27 May, it was estimated that 2,000 people may have died by the landslide in Yambali village alone. These numbers were not confirmed by government officials. On 29 May, councillor and chair of the Mulitaka Disaster Committee Jaman Yandam said that more than 160 people had died, citing village leaders who had conducted a head count. As of 6 June, the official death toll cited by the government was 670.

sentences.text: Over 4,000 people were directly affected. Twelve bodies, At least 17 people were injured and four others were rescued, while 1,182 homes were reported to have been destroyed or buried. More than 5,000 pigs, 100 stores, and five vehicles were also believed to have been buried, as well as two health centres. An additional 250 homes were condemned due to unstable ground conditions,<ref name="apleg"/> displacing about 1,650 people.<ref name="official670"/>

sentences.text: {{quote box| width=260px| border=1px| align=right|fontsize=88%| quote=Queen Camilla|My wife and I were deeply shocked and saddened to learn of the devastating landslide in Enga, and the tragic loss of so many lives, homes and food gardens. [...] I have faith that your communities will come together to support the survivors and the recovery in these heartbreaking circumstances.| salign=right| source=Charles III, King of Papua New Guinea, 2024}}

references.text: <ref>{{cite news|work=Sky News|title=Papua New Guinea: More than 2,000 people buried alive in landslide - as 'major destruction' hampers rescue efforts|date=27 May 2024|url=https://news.sky.com/story/papua-new-guinea-more-than-4-000-people-impacted-by-landslide-13143217|access-date=26 May 2024|archive-date=26 May 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240526044232/https://news.sky.com/story/papua-new-guinea-more-than-4-000-people-impacted-by-landslide-13143217|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: Prime Minister James Marape announced that the Papua New Guinea Defence Force was sent to the scene to conduct relief work, recover bodies, and rebuild destroyed infrastructure. Police, medics, engineers, and United Nations personnel were also dispatched, while some locals acted as first responders. By dusk, rescuers at the scene utilized a mechanical digger and tools in an attempt to locate survivors. The Papua New Guinea government formally requested aid from the United Nations and other countries on 26 May. with authorities saying that nearly 7,900 people living near the disaster site were at risk from further landslides. Condolences were sent by Governor-General Bob Dadae and King Charles III.

sentences.text: International humanitarian agency CARE and the Papua New Guinea Red Cross Society said that they were assessing the situation. CARE later said around 4,000 people were in need of humanitarian aid following the disaster, including individuals displaced during February 2024 Enga Province massacre|intertribal clashes in February 2024. with Australia subsequently providing up to AU$4.5 million in funds and a disaster response team. The Australian Defence Force and the Queensland Fire and Emergency Services were also deployed to assist in relief efforts. The Government of India|Indian government announced relief assistance of US$1 million on 28 May, reaffirming the two countries' ties under the Forum for India–Pacific Islands Cooperation|Forum for India-Pacific Islands Cooperation (FIPIC). The European Union released 150,000 euros in aid, while USAID provided two million kina ($500,000). On 28 May, the New Zealand Government pledged NZ$1.5 million in relief support and announced plans to deploy a New Zealand Defence Force C-130 aircraft carrying relief supplies and technical expertise. Japan provided K3.81 million ($1 million) in aid through UNICEF. The Chinese embassy dispatched a medical team to Mulitaka to treat landslide victims.

sentences.text: The provincial governments of Hela Province|Hela and Southern Highlands Province|Southern Highlands pledged K1 million in aid each, while ICTSI South Pacific and Newmont also pledged K1 million, respectively.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |title=Prime Minister visits landslide-affected area in Enga Province |date=2 June 2024 |url=https://www.postcourier.com.pg/prime-minister-visits-landslide-affected-area-in-enga-province/ |access-date=2 June 2024 |publisher=Papua New Guinea Post-Courier |language=en |archive-date=2 June 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240602041735/https://www.postcourier.com.pg/prime-minister-visits-landslide-affected-area-in-enga-province/ |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: Rescue work was hampered by large rocks and fallen trees, with the Red Cross estimating that it would take up to two days for humanitarian assistance to arrive. Police Commander Martin Kelei reported that recovery efforts were further complicated by the potential danger of additional landslides caused by removing debris, while Coordinator for CARE Australia Justine McMahon stated that instability and shifting of the disaster site and forecasts of future rain could lead to further landslides, threatening rescuers and aid staff. The UN migration agency of Papua New Guinea's Serhan Aktoprak reported that the landslide engulfed and blocked three streams located near the villages affected, soaking the ground even more and increasing the risk of future landslides in the recovery area. According to ABC News (United States)|ABC News, only helicopters could access Kaokalam.

<ref name="APNews" /> Clearing of the blocked highway was also delayed due to opposition from some of the relatives of the victims, who called for the site to be preserved in situ as a memorial.<ref>{{Cite web |last=McGuirk |first=Rod |date=31 May 2024 |title=Papua New Guinea's prime minister visits the site of a landslide estimated to have killed hundreds |url=https://apnews.com/article/papua-new-guinea-landslide-4743a701cbd8deb17263b8fd9b954083 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240531211559/https://apnews.com/article/papua-new-guinea-landslide-4743a701cbd8deb17263b8fd9b954083 |archive-date=31 May 2024 |access-date=2024-05-31 |website=Associated Press |publisher= |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: Humanitarian convoys were deployed by road from the provincial capital Wabag toward the disaster zone beginning on 25 May and were escorted by the Papua New Guinea Defence Force to protect the convoys as they passed through Tambitanis, where intertribal clashes resulted in 8 deaths and the burning of 35 homes and businesses. Defense Minister Billy Joseph and PNG National Disaster Centre director Laso Mana visited Wabag on 26 May to assess recovery efforts. The National Disaster Centre released K500,000 in aid to the Enga provincial government. Heavy equipment arrived at the site on 26 May, with more expected to be delivered by the Papua New Guinea Defence Force from Lae as early as 28 May. Authorities also announced plans to quarantine the disaster zone to prevent the spread of disease.

references.text: <ref name="apleg"/> The Porgera mine also pledged to provide mechanical diggers to help in rescue and road-clearing operations.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Rescuers fear new slips at deadly Papua New Guinea landslide |date=27 May 2024 |url=https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20240527-rescuers-fear-new-slips-at-deadly-papua-new-guinea-landslide |access-date=2024-05-27 |publisher=France 24 |language=en }}</ref>

<ref name=":0" /> Aid groups expressed concerns over the landslide's effects on youth, who make up 40% of the affected population. At least nine children were orphaned by the landslide.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Aid reaches Papua New Guinea landslide site |date=29 May 2024 |url=https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20240529-aid-reaches-papua-new-guinea-landslide-site |access-date=2024-05-29 |publisher=France 24 |language=en |archive-date=29 May 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240529090856/https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20240529-aid-reaches-papua-new-guinea-landslide-site |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: A minute of silence was held at the National Parliament of Papua New Guinea to commemorate the victims. On 31 May, Marape visited the site of the landslide and pledged K20 million towards reconstruction efforts.

references.text: <ref name="abc160"/> During a parliamentary session on 30 May 2024, Speaker Job Pomat reprimanded MPs for a muted response to the disaster, which occurred amid plans to file a no-confidence motion against Marape.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Wiseman |first=Don |date=29 May 2024 |title=Papua New Guinea leaders voice profound concern for landslide victims |url=https://www.rnz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/518230/papua-new-guinea-leaders-voice-profound-concern-for-landslide-victims |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240530014934/https://www.rnz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/518230/papua-new-guinea-leaders-voice-profound-concern-for-landslide-victims |archive-date=30 May 2024 |access-date=2024-05-29 |website=Radio New Zealand |publisher= |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 5 June, the military announced that all efforts to recover more bodies would halt due to the danger of further landslides and that access to the site would be restricted.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-06-05 |title=Body recovery 'called off' at Papua New Guinea landslide site |url=https://sg.news.yahoo.com/body-recovery-called-off-papua-043030458.html |access-date=2024-06-05 |website=Yahoo News |language=en-SG |archive-date=5 June 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240605092703/https://sg.news.yahoo.com/body-recovery-called-off-papua-043030458.html |url-status=live }}</ref>
